New Orleans program steers women leaving prison to careers in health care
BY JOHN SIMERMAN | Staff writer
Nov 17, 2022
5 min to read
1 of 3
Participants of Operation Restoration learn how to do a urine culture test at the New Orleans Career Center in New Orleans, Monday, Oct. 3, 2022. Operation Restoration is a group that helps train formerly incarcerated women and family members effected by incarceration to become medical lab assistants. (Photo by Sophia Germer, NOLA.com, The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate)
Sophia Germer

Zelda Welch received an 18-year prison sentence for a raft of thievery in Jefferson Parish, but she won parole after eight years thanks to a slate of 2017 reforms that helped slim a state incarceration rate that led the nation.
Welch, 54, said she came out of prison eager to impress employers, even if it meant free tryouts, “just to gain their trust, to show them I learned from my mistakes and that this is my past and it doesn’t disqualify me for a better future.”
Rotanya Fair and Mykelle Dawson go over a quiz results at the New Orleans Career Center in New Orleans, Monday, Oct. 3, 2022. Operation Restoration is a group that helps train formerly incarcerated women and family members effected by incarceration to become medical lab assistants. (Photo by Sophia Germer, NOLA.com, The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate)
Sophia Germer
Such hopes drew Welch and more than a dozen other women to the New Orleans Career Center in Treme over the past few months to attend a new training program aimed at clearing a path to careers in health care for women out of prison or impacted by it.
They logged hours studying “Essentials of Medical Laboratory Practice," peering into microscopes, and learning urinalysis and other protocols — the mechanics of working in a hospital or private lab.
It marked the third class for an upstart program launched this year by Operation Restoration, an advocacy group founded by Syrita Steib, whose own prison-to-success story helped win her a pardon from President Donald Trump in 2020.
Kamisha Redmond looks at a fecal culture slide at the New Orleans Career Center in New Orleans, Monday, Oct. 3, 2022. Operation Restoration is a group that helps train formerly incarcerated women and family members effected by incarceration to become medical lab assistants. (Photo by Sophia Germer, NOLA.com, The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate)
Sophia Germer
Steib led a successful campaign that made Louisiana the first state to “ban the box” indicating criminal convictions on college applications. This month, she took a run at elected politics, finishing fourth in a race to unseat U.S. Sen. John Kennedy, who won handily.
Steib is also a program model. Imprisoned as a teen after pleading guilty to participating in a burglary and arson in Texas, she served more than nine years and then yearned to become a doctor.
Denied acceptance to the University of New Orleans, she removed the check mark from the box, reapplied and got in. Steib went on to a laboratory science degree at LSU’s Health Sciences Center, working at Ochsner and other hospitals before shifting to advocacy.
“The hoops that we have to jump through to make people think you are valuable, you are important, to make people take a chance on you … and it’s all based on this conviction,” Steib said.
Instructor Pearl Thompson teaches participants of Operation Restoration how to test urine with chem strips at the New Orleans Career Center in New Orleans, Monday, Oct. 3, 2022. Operation Restoration is a group that helps train formerly incarcerated women and family members effected by incarceration to become medical lab assistants. (Photo by Sophia Germer, NOLA.com, The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate)
Sophia Germer
“I just wanted to create pathways for women who had been impacted by incarceration to get into careers in the medical field in a low-barrier, entry level. And then it’s like, hey, the sky's the limit.”
The nascent program is among a smattering devoted to smoothing the path to reentry for women prisoners in Louisiana, who comprise a small minority of the inmate population but can face crushing barriers. 
Kamisha Redmond and Mykelle Dawson work together to read a chem strip used to test urine at the New Orleans Career Center in New Orleans, Monday, Oct. 3, 2022. Operation Restoration is a group that helps train formerly incarcerated women and family members effected by incarceration to become medical lab assistants. (Photo by Sophia Germer, NOLA.com, The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate)
Sophia Germer
Women account for just 5% of prisoners in state custody — with about 1,400 now in state or local facilities, down from more than 2,000 in 2017, according to state data. Half of women prisoners are in for drug or property crimes.
Domestic or sexual violence factor into the histories of many women prisoners, two-thirds of whom have a history of mental health problems.
A state task force on women’s incarceration issued a 2020 report that also found a rate of post-traumatic stress disorder three times higher for imprisoned women than men. Most women prisoners have minor children.
Steib sat on the state task force, which also found few transitional work programs focused on women prisoners.
Rotanya Fair and Mykelle Dawson go over a quiz results at the New Orleans Career Center in New Orleans, Monday, Oct. 3, 2022. Operation Restoration is a group that helps train formerly incarcerated women and family members effected by incarceration to become medical lab assistants. (Photo by Sophia Germer, NOLA.com, The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate)
Sophia Germer
Reentry and other prisoner programs are often geared toward the much larger male populations, said Susan Dewey, a University of Alabama criminology professor who studies incarcerated women.
“They’re the forgotten offenders,” she said. “Post-prison trauma in itself is real. Add to that a woman who has a serious and persistent mental health issue, and we have a real recipe for hardship. She’s going on the street already 10 steps behind.”
A state corrections spokesman said the COVID-19 pandemic shelved plans for the agency to team with Operation Restoration to create a lab training program within the women’s prison in St. Gabriel. Spokesman Ken Pastorick said talks to resurrect that plan are starting up.
In the meantime, Operation Restoration currently offers a bachelor's program in partnership with Tulane University to women prisoners. Pastorick pointed to literacy, cosmetology, horticulture and other programs available to them, while noting limitations.
Flooding of the women's prison six years ago left corrections officials to divide those prisoners among state and local facilities. Prison officials have promised expanded programs for women with a new $146 million facility due to open in late 2024.
Dewey praised Louisiana officials for their efforts, while highlighting “enormous” challenges for women exiting prison, including stigma.
“The expectation is women will always be the caregivers and that women who have struggled with addiction somehow are bad mothers choosing drugs over their children,” Dewey said, “not recognizing the fact the majority of women have been victims of trauma.”
Welch described a history of abuse before a habit of stealing credit cards led to guilty pleas to 11 felony counts and a lengthy prison term as a habitual offender.
Kamisha Redmond and Mykelle Dawson work together to read a chem strip used to test urine at the New Orleans Career Center in New Orleans, Monday, Oct. 3, 2022. Operation Restoration is a group that helps train formerly incarcerated women and family members effected by incarceration to become medical lab assistants. (Photo by Sophia Germer, NOLA.com, The Times-Picayune | The New Orleans Advocate)
Sophia Germer
She grew up poor in the Fisher public housing project in Algiers, where she said she was molested and had her first baby at age 14, dropping out of school. In 1999, Welch said, her ex-husband “left me for dead” in Harvey after she threatened to leave.
“He drug me into that house and beat me in different areas,” she said. “I deal with the pain almost every day, with the swelling.”
If anything, she said, prison taught her persistence.
“It’s your past, but it still haunts you sometimes,” she said. “I know I didn’t survive through this life of being abused, misused and everything just to be thrown to the trash. And I want to make something of myself.”
A mother and daughter duo have been among the students enrolled since the first lab training class rolled out in April.
Abrais Nedd, 37, described a hectic life as she settled behind a table at the front of the class recently. She gave birth this year while locked up in the St. Tammany Parish jail, she said, and for months tried to bond with her infant son in Zoom calls.
Nedd said she landed in a mental health institution before her recent criminal trouble but was now living in a New Orleans shelter and arranging visits with her baby, who is now in foster care. A felony charge looms for obstruction of justice, an allegation she denies but can't shake.
“When I found out about this (program), I thought it was maybe something I could do to earn a living where my background may not be a factor,” she said.
Through grants, Operation Restoration also provides laptops, child care, rides and other support to help recently incarcerated women land on their feet.
The third class for lab assistant training graduated 14 women, including Nedd and Welch, though the successes so far in securing jobs and licenses for graduates has been lean.
At least two women have gained jobs through the program since the first class in April, one at a local hospital and the other in a private lab, said the instructors.
The licensing includes a background check and can take six months. So far, none of the women in the program has gained a license from the state Board of Medical Examiners.
Dr. Vincent Culotta, executive director for the board, said a criminal conviction may not disqualify an applicant, though each is investigated for a decision to approve, deny, or attach probation to a license. He said the board has helped Operation Restoration with the application process, including creating a system to let it pay the fees for students in the training. 
As she praised the organization’s housing director, Dolfinette Martin, for taking an interest, Nedd suggested there's more to the training program than a license. 
“Everything that I’m going through, she’s been teaching me I can trust again,” said Nedd, “that everybody is not going to hurt me. That they’re here to help me.”
